The [[Ceremonial counties of England|English ceremonial county]] of [[Somerset]] contains a wide range of [[museum]]s, defined here as institutions (including [[nonprofit organisation]]s, government entities, and private [[business]]es) that collect and care for objects of cultural, artistic, scientific, or historical interest and make their collections or related exhibits available for public viewing. Non-profit [[Art museum|art galleries]] and university art galleries are also included, but museums that exist only in cyberspace (i.e., [[virtual museum]]s) are not.

Many of the museums are in [[listed building]]s. In the United Kingdom, this signifies a building which has been placed on the Statutory List of Buildings of Special Architectural or Historic Interest. In [[England and Wales]], the authority for listing is granted by the [[Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990]], and is presently administered by [[English Heritage]]. Listed buildings in danger of decay are included on English Heritage's [[Buildings at Risk Register]]. There are three types of listed status: Grade I, for buildings &quot;of exceptional interest, sometimes considered to be internationally important&quot;; Grade II*, for &quot;particularly important buildings of more than special interest&quot;; and Grade II, for buildings that are &quot;nationally important and of special interest&quot;.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Listed buildings|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/protecting/heritage-protection/what-can-we-protect/listed-buildings/|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;

Many of the museums have been accredited by the [[Museums, Libraries and Archives Council]], which sets national standards for museums in the UK.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Accreditation Scheme|url=http://www.mla.gov.uk/what/raising_standards/accreditation|publisher=The [[Museums, Libraries and Archives Council]] (MLA)|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Several are [[art gallery|art galleries]] providing space for the [[art exhibition|exhibition of art]], or are [[Philatelic Museum|philatelic]], [[Regimental museum|regimental]], [[Science museum|science]], [[Aviation museum|aviation]], [[Transport museum|transport]], [[Railway museum|railway]], [[Toy museum|toy]], religious or sports museums, but the majority are [[local museum]]s. There are also several [[historic house museum]]s owned or managed by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] or [[English Heritage]].

| [[American Museum in Britain]]||[[File:American Museum in Bath.jpg|100px]] || [[Claverton, Somerset|Claverton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3768|-2.311|type:landmark_region:GB|name=American Museum in Britain}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || [[Art museum|Art]] || The house, designed by [[Jeffry Wyatville]] and built in the 1820s,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Claverton Manor|url=http://www.gardenvisit.com/garden/claverton_manor_garden|publisher=Garden Visit|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; on the site of a manor bought by [[Ralph Allen]] in 1758,&lt;ref name=&quot;scott&quot;&gt;{{cite book |title=The hidden places of Somerset |last=Scott |first=Shane |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1995 |publisher=Travel Publishing Ltd |location=Aldermaston |isbn=1902007018 |pages=16–17 }}&lt;/ref&gt; is now a Grade&amp;nbsp;I [[listed building]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Claverton Manor (The American Museum) | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?pid=2&amp;id=399485|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | accessdate=16 December 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum was founded by two antique collectors, American [[Dallas Pratt]] and Briton [[John Judkyn]], and opened to the public for the first time on 1&amp;nbsp;July 1961. The exhibits cover every period of [[American history]], but because Judkyn was a peace-loving [[Quaker]], the museum contains no [[militaria]]. Included are 200&amp;nbsp;[[quilt]]s and coverlets, and several pieces of [[Shaker]] furniture.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=American Museum in Britain|url=http://www.americanmuseum.org/|publisher=American Museum in Britain|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Ashton Windmill]]||align=center |[[File:Chapel Allerton - Ashton Windmill - geograph.org.uk - 83605.jpg|80px]] || [[Chapel Allerton, Somerset|Chapel Allerton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2488|-2.8402|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ashton Windmill}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Mill || A [[tower mill]] dating from the 18th&amp;nbsp;century, it was modernised in 1900 with machinery brought from the demolished [[Moorlinch]] mill, and iron hoops were added around the building.&lt;ref name=&quot;coulthrad&quot;&gt;{{cite book |title=Windmills of Somerset and the men who worked them |last=Coulthard |first=Alfred J. |authorlink= |coauthors=Martin Watts |year=1978 |publisher=Research Publishing Co|location=London |isbn=0705000605 |pages=42–44 }}&lt;/ref&gt; It was restored in 1967. The mill has been designated by [[English Heritage]] as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=268760 |title=Ashton windmill |accessdate=3 March 2008 |format= |work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] }}&lt;/ref&gt; Now preserved, it was given to [[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery|Bristol City Museum]] in 1966. It is currently owned by [[Sedgemoor|Sedgemoor District Council]], and maintained by volunteers. In 2010, Sedgemoor Council decided it could no longer afford to maintain the windmill, and appealed for an independent group of trustees to take on responsibility for the building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=Windmill appeal|date=April 2010|publisher=[[Mendip Times]]|pages=8|accessdate=1 April 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bakelite Museum]]||[[File:The Bakelite Museum, Williton - geograph.org.uk - 1024873.jpg|100px]] || [[Williton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1648|-3.3087|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bakelite Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] ||Multiple || The museum is housed in the Orchard Millhouse, which has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Orchard Millhouse | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=265006 | accessdate=30 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is home to a collection of vintage plastics ranging from radios, cameras and telephones to a [[Bakelite]] coffin.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bakerlite Museum|url=http://www.bakelitmuseum.de/home/home1024e.htm|publisher=Bakerlite Museum|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Barrington Court]]||[[File:Barringtoncourt.jpg|100px]] ||[[Barrington, Somerset|Barrington]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9626|-2.877|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Barrington Court}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || [[Historic house museum|Historic house]] || A [[Tudor Style architecture|Tudor]] [[manor house]] begun ''c.''&amp;nbsp;1538 and completed in the late 1550s, with a vernacular 17th-century stable court (1675), it was the first house acquired by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]], in 1907,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Barrington Court|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-barringtoncourt/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and was leased to Col. Lyle of [[Tate &amp; Lyle]] in the 1920s. Barrington Court has an [[Arts and Crafts Movement|Arts and Crafts]]-style gardens for which [[garden design]]er [[Gertrude Jekyll]] provided planting plans.&lt;ref&gt;Jekyll, G. ''[http://www.archive.org/details/colourinflowerg00jekygoog Colour in the flower garden]'' (London: Country Life, 1908).&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bath Abbey#Heritage Vaults Museum|Bath Abbey Heritage Vaults Museum]]||align=center |[[File:060529-17-BathAbbey.jpg|80px]] || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3815|-2.3587|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bath Abbey Heritage Vaults Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Religious || Located in the restored 18th&amp;nbsp;century cellars, the museum features artefacts and exhibits about the [[Bath Abbey]]'s history.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://search.visitbritain.com/en-EN/Details.aspx?ContentID=504359&amp;IndustryType=13&amp;Location=Somerset%2c+England&amp;PropertySubType=6&amp;IsSearchFormAccommodation=False|title=Bath Abbey Heritage Vaults Museum|publisher=Visit Britain|accessdate=4 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Displays include the different buildings on the site and their uses, the Abbey's impact on the community, the construction, architecture and sculptures of the buildings, artefacts and sculptures, and the role of the Abbey in present times.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Vaults Museum|url=http://www.bathabbey.org/museum.htm|publisher=Bath Abbey|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bath Postal Museum]]||[[File:Bath Postal Museum.jpg|100px]] || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3815|-2.3587|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bath Postal Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || [[Philatelic Museum|Philatelic]] || The museum was founded in 1979. In 1984 it moved to a home in Broad Street, which was the site of Bath's main [[Post Office]] from 1822 to 1854.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bathpostalmuseum.co.uk/about.html |title=About us |accessdate=27 October 2007 |work=Bath Postal Museum }}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Bath Postal Museum | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=444586 | accessdate=27 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; Artefacts on display included [[quills]] and ink wells, stamp boxes, post boxes, [[post horn]]s, [[clay tablet]]s, strip maps, model [[mail coach]]es, letters and postcards. There is also a replica [[Victorian era|Victorian]] [[post office]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bath Postal Museum|url=http://www.bathpostalmuseum.co.uk/index.html|publisher=Bath Postal Museum|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution (BRLSI)|Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution]]||align=center |–|| [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3836|-2.3636|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Multiple || The Institution's antiquarian library contains over 7,000&amp;nbsp;volumes, and includes the Jenyns and the [[Christopher Edmund Broome|Broome]] natural history libraries. Its archives contain bound volumes of letters from eminent scientists and naturalists such as [[Charles Darwin]], Professor [[John Stevens Henslow]] and [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|Sir Joseph Dalton Hooker]]. Smaller collections cover theology, government, travel and local history. Four paintings by [[Andrea Casali]] and a photography collection by the Reverend [[Francis Lockey]] (1796–1869) are also featured.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=BRLSI Museum|url=http://www.brlsi.org/museum/|publisher=Bath Royal Literary and Science Institution|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is housed in 16–18, [[Queen Square (Bath)|Queen Square]], a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed [[Greek Revival]] building designed by [[John Pinch the younger]] in 1830.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title= QUEEN SQUARE (west side) | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=443386 | accessdate=10 January 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Beckford's Tower|Beckford's Tower and Museum]]||align=center |[[File:Beckfords Tower.jpg|80px]] || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.4066|-2.3789|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Beckford's Tower and Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Biographical || The {{convert|120|ft|m|adj=on}} high Beckford's Tower was completed in 1827. It contains a collection of furniture, paintings and art that belonged to the writer, collector and patron of the arts [[William Thomas Beckford|William Beckford]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Beckford's Tower and Museum|url=http://www.bath-preservation-trust.org.uk/?id=9|publisher=[[Bath Preservation Trust]]|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The tower is owned by the [[Bath Preservation Trust]] and managed by the Beckford Tower Trust. It is available to rent as a holiday home through the [[Landmark Trust]], and has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Beckford's Tower &amp; Mortuary Chapel, Lansdown Cemetery | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=442844 | accessdate=2 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bishops Lydeard Mill and Rural Life Museum]]||[[File:Bishops Lydeard Mill.jpg|100px]] || [[Bishops Lydeard]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0546|-3.1855|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bishops Lydeard Mill}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Mill ||The building dates from the 18th&amp;nbsp;century. It has an [[Water wheel#Overshot wheel|overshot waterwheel]] and has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=The old mill and millhouse|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=270244|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Since 2000, the building has been renovated. It was opened by the town Mayor in 2003.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bishops Lydeard Mill and Rural Life Museum|url=http://www.visitsomerset.co.uk/site/things-to-see-and-do/bishops-lydeard-mill-and-rural-life-museum-p589373|publisher=Visit Somerset|accessdate=16 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The water wheel weighs over two tonnes and is driven by water from Back Stream, which originates in the [[Brendon Hills]].&lt;ref name=&quot;somersetguide&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Bishops Lydeard Mill|url=http://www.somersettouristguide.com/Taunton/Bishops_Lydeard_Mill_789.asp|publisher=Somerset Guide|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum focuses on traditional trades and crafts, including a [[wheelwright|wheelwright's]] shop, [[Cooper (profession)|cooper's]] shop, [[Saddle|saddler's]] shop, [[blacksmith|blacksmith's]] shop and a [[Victorian era|Victorian]] kitchen.&lt;ref name=&quot;somersetguide&quot;/&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bishops Lydyeard Mill|url=http://www.bishopslydeardmill.co.uk/|publisher=Bishops Lydyeard Mill|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bishop's Palace, Wells|Bishop's Palace]]||[[File:Bishopspalacewells.jpg|100px]] || [[Wells]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2093|-2.64255|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bishop's Palace, Wells}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Historic house || The medieval palace home of the Bishops of Bath and Wells has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=The Bishop's Palace and Bishop's House | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=483259 | accessdate=10 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; The building was begun around 1210 by Bishop [[Jocelin of Wells]], but principally dates from 1230. It was restored, divided, and the upper storey added by [[Benjamin Ferrey]] between 1846 and 1854. The chapel was built between 1275 and 1292 for Bishop [[Robert Burnell]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=The Bishop's Chapel | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=483260 | accessdate=10 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; The gatehouse has a bridge over the [[moat]], and dates from 1341.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Gatehouse and boundary wall with bridge over moat | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=483262 | accessdate=10 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are {{convert|14|acre|ha|1}} of gardens, including St. Andrew's Spring, from which the city takes its name.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bishops Palace and Gardens|url=http://www.bishopspalacewells.co.uk/index.php|publisher=Bishops Palace and Gardens|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Blagdon Lake|Blagdon Lake Pumping Station and Visitor Centre]]||[[File:Blagdonpump.jpg|100px]] || [[Blagdon]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.209293|-2.64255|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Blagdon Lake Pumping Station and Visitor Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || [[Science museum|Technology]] || The museum includes science and environment exhibits and hands-on displays as well as a room dedicated to the charity [[WaterAid]]. One of the two steam-driven [[beam engine]]s is still working occasionally. Outside, there is a nature trail and space for picnics.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Blagdon Lake Visitor Centre|url=http://www.bristolwater.co.uk/leisure/blagdon-info.asp|publisher=Bristol Water|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1984, it was decided to preserve the two remaining engines and incorporate them as the central feature in the visitor centre, including a museum in the old boiler house, which opened in 1988 and attracts over 30,000 visitors a year. The pumping station is now a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Blagdon Pumping Station | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33896 | accessdate=9 May 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Blake Museum]]||align=center |–|| [[Bridgwater]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1285|-2.9938|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Blake Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || [[Local museum|Local]] ||The building is believed to be the birthplace of [[Robert Blake (admiral)|Robert Blake, General at Sea (1599–1657)]]. It was built in the late 15th or early 16th&amp;nbsp;century, and has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=The Admiral Blake Museum | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=373830 | accessdate=30 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; Particular features of the museum, founded in 1926, are artefacts from Blake's life, including his sea chest.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.cornucopia.org.uk/html/search/verb/ListIdentifiers/set/location/1889 |title= Blake Museum|accessdate=27 October 2007 |format= |work=Cornucopia }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Blake Museum|url=http://www.bridgwatermuseum.org.uk/|publisher=Blake Museum|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Blue Anchor railway station#Museum|Blue Anchor Railway Museum]]||[[File:Blue Anchor station down side.jpg|100px]] || [[Blue Anchor]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1815|-3.4024|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Blue Anchor Railway Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || [[Railway museum|Railway]] || The station buildings have been restored and the waiting room on the westbound platform was converted to a [[railway museum]] in 1985. It opened in 1986 under the auspices of the West Somerset Railway Steam Trust. Staffing is provided by the Friends of Blue Anchor Railway Museum, who also undertake fundraising activities.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Blue Anchor Station|url=http://www.wsr.org.uk/ba.htm|publisher=West Somerset Railway|accessdate=7 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum now contains around 550&amp;nbsp;items, mainly related to the [[Great Western Railway]] or other West Country lines.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Blue Anchor Railway Museum|url=http://www.wssrt.co.uk/museum.htm|publisher=West Somerset Steam Railway Trust|accessdate=7 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Bruton Museum]]||align=center |–|| [[Bruton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.112|-2.45|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bruton Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || The museum is housed in the Dovecote Building, in Bruton's High Street.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bruton Museum|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6592|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum|url=http://brutontown.co.uk/history/museum.html|publisher=Bruton Town|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Building of Bath Collection]]||align=center |–|| [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3794|-2.36|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Building of Bath Collection}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || History || The collection contains architectural models, maps, paintings and reconstructions showing how a typical [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] house was constructed.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Building of Bath Collection|url=http://www.bath-preservation-trust.org.uk/?id=4|publisher=[[Bath Preservation Trust]]|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Castle Cary and District Museum]]||[[File:Market House Castle Cary.jpg|100px]] ||[[Castle Cary]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0896|-2.5141|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Castle Cary and District Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || The museum is housed in the Market House, a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Market House|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=262020|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; There is a varied collection of exhibits; the earliest are local [[fossil]]s including [[ammonites]], with a display about the discovery of an [[ichthyosaurus]] at [[Alford, Somerset|Alford]]. Local industry and agriculture are represented by displays on the production of rope and hemp.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Castle Cary and District Museum|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6593|publisher=South Somerset District Council|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are also examples of agricultural implements, tools and relics,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Castle Cary Museum |url=http://www.castlecarymuseum.org.uk/|publisher=Castle Cary Museum|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; with an explanation of the local geology. Information is also provided about [[Cary Castle]], and a room is dedicated to the life and work of Parson [[James Woodforde]].
|-
| [[Chard Museum]]||[[File:Chard Museum.jpg|100px]] ||[[Chard, Somerset|Chard]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.8728|-2.9587|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Chard Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || Housed in a 16th&amp;nbsp;century [[thatch]]ed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Chard Museum|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=374127|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=23 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;themuseum&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=The Story of Chard Museum|url=http://www.chardmuseum.co.uk/The_Museum/|publisher=Chard Museum|accessdate=23 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Chard and district museum|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6594|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=23 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Exhibits tell the story of the town and the local area including the geology, the fire of 1577, the [[Monmouth Rebellion]], and the local lace mills.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Chard &amp; District Museum|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000020|publisher=[[Culture24]]|accessdate=23 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Outside there is a [[blacksmith]]'s [[forge]] and display of farm machinery.&lt;ref name=&quot;wessextourist&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Chard Museum|url=http://www.wessex.me.uk/char_mus.html|publisher=Wessex Tourist Board|accessdate=23 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are also displays on notable people with connections to the town: [[John Stringfellow]] and [[William Samuel Henson]], who achieved the first powered flight,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|last=Parramore|first=Thomas C.|title=First to Fly: North Carolina and the Beginnings of Aviation|year=2007|publisher=The University of North Carolina Press|isbn=978-0807854709|pages=46|url=http://books.google.com/?id=zrpb67qFXUIC&amp;pg=PT63&amp;dq=1857+Temple+flight&amp;q=1857%20Temple%20flight| accessdate=6 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=High hopes for replica plane|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1591057.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 May 2010 | date=10 October 2001}}&lt;/ref&gt; [[James Gillingham]], who pioneered the development of articulated [[artificial limb]]s,&lt;ref name=ChardFirst&gt;{{cite news | url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/opinion/main.jhtml?xml=/opinion/2006/10/07/dl0703.xml | title= Chard was there first | publisher= Daily Telegraph | date= 7 October 2006 | accessdate=17 October 2008 | location=London}}&lt;/ref&gt; Corporal [[Samuel Vickery]] who was awarded the [[Victoria Cross]] in 1897 during the [[Tirah Campaign]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book| first=David| last=Harvey| year=1999| title=Monuments to Courage : Victoria Cross Headstones and Memorials. Vol.1, 1854–1916| publisher= Kevin &amp; Kay Patience| oclc=59437297}}&lt;/ref&gt; and [[Margaret Bondfield]], the UK's first woman cabinet minister.&lt;ref name=&quot;tuc&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.unionhistory.info/timeline/Tl_Display.php?Where=Dc1Title+contains+%27Margaret+Bondfield+(1873-1953)%27+|title=Margaret Bondfield (1873–1953)|work=Timeline|publisher=TUC History|accessdate=29 March 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Cheddar Gorge|Cheddar Caves and Gorge]]||[[File:Cheddargorge01.jpg|100px]] || [[Cheddar]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2824|-2.7655|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cheddar Caves and Gorge}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Archaeology || This includes the [[Cheddar Man]] Museum of Prehistory, which contains information about the caves and their [[paleontology|palaeontological]] development. The exhibits include original [[flint]] tools and human remains excavated from the caves.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Cheddar Gorge and Caves|url=http://www.cheddarcaves.co.uk/|publisher=Cheddar Gorge and Caves|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Claverton Pumping Station]]||[[File:Claverton Pumping Station Exterior.JPG|100px]] || [[Claverton, Somerset|Claverton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3781|-2.3017|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Claverton Pumping Station}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Technology || A water pumping station with waterwheel that pumps water from the [[River Avon, Bristol|River Avon]] to the [[Kennet and Avon Canal]] using power from the flow of the River Avon;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Claverton Pumping Station|url=http://www.claverton.org/|publisher=Claverton Pumping Station|accessdate=24 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; it has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title= Claverton Pumping Station | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=399483 | accessdate=9 May 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Cleeve Abbey]]||[[File:CleeveAbbeyDormitoryC.jpg|100px]] || [[Washford]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1556|-3.3642|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cleeve Abbey}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Religious || At this site there are the remains of a medieval [[monastery]] founded in the late 12th&amp;nbsp;century,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Cleeve Abbey|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/cleeve-abbey/|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=25 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; which have been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Cleeve Abbey|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=264814|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=3 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and it is listed as a [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=264814 |title=Cleeve Abbey |work=[[Images of England]] |publisher=[[English Heritage]] |accessdate=13 July 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Clevedon Court]]||[[File:Clevedoncourt.jpg|100px]] ||[[Clevedon]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.4407|-2.8335|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Clevedon Court}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, this 14th-century manor house contains collections of [[Nailsea]] glass and Eltonware pottery.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Clevedon Court|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-clevedoncourt/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=25 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=33130 |title=Clevedon Court |accessdate=16 March 2008 |work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] }}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Coleridge Cottage]]||[[File:Coleridge cottage.jpg|100px]] || [[Nether Stowey]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1521|-3.1537|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Coleridge Cottage}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, this home of poet [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]] was constructed in the 17th&amp;nbsp;century.&lt;ref name=&quot;Coleridge Cottage&quot;&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.friendsofcoleridge.com/Coleridge-Cottage.htm |title= Coleridge Cottage|accessdate=16 November 2007 |work=Friends of Coleridge }}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=No 35 (Coleridge's Cottage) and No 37 | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=268906 | accessdate=16 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Cothay Manor]]||[[File:Cothay Manor.jpg|100px]] ||[[Stawley]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9729|-3.3418|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cothay Manor}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Historic house || A 15th-century medieval manor and gardens,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Cothay Manor|url=http://www.cothaymanor.co.uk/|publisher=Cothay Manor|accessdate=26 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; built around 1480, it now has a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listing,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=270099|title=Cothay Manor|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=17 October 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is considered by many to be the most perfect of small, classic, medieval buildings in England today, rating four stars in [[Simon Jenkins]]' ''England’s Thousand Best Houses.''&lt;ref name=&quot;BBCSomerset&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/somerset/content/articles/2008/06/13/heart_of_a_garden_feature.shtml|title='Romantic' Cothay Manor's garden delights|publisher=BBC Somerset|accessdate=9 December 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Crewkerne and District Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Crewkerne]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.8854|-2.7951|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Crewkerne and District Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || The museum opened in 2000 in an old house with an 18th-century frontage. It was restored with the help of grants from the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]], [[Somerset County Council]], [[South Somerset]] District Council and Crewkerne Town Council. Exhibits cover the development of Crewkerne during the 18th and 19th centuries, with particular emphasis on the [[flax]] and [[linen]] industry.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Crewkerne Heritage Centre|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6595|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=27 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Other collections relate to local archaeology, coins and medals, costume and textiles, fine art, music, personalities, science and technology, social history, weapons and war.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Crewkerne Museum|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000033|publisher=[[Culture24]]|accessdate=27 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Dunster Castle]]||[[File:Dunster Castle.jpg|100px]] ||[[Dunster]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1825|-3.4459|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Dunster Castle}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] ||Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, Dunster is a medieval castle with 19th-century remodelling.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Dunster Castle|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-dunstercastle.htm|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=26 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Dunster Castle and gatehouse| work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=264651 | accessdate=7 February 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; During 2009 it received 134,502 visitors.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Visits made in 2009 to visitor attractions|url=http://www.alva.org.uk/visitor_statistics/|publisher=Association of leading visitor attractions|accessdate=12 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is home to the [[NCCPG National Plant Collection|National Plant Collection]] of [[Arbutus unedo|Strawberry Tree]]s.
|-
| [[Dunster Doll Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Dunster]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1824|-3.4459|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Dunster Doll Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || [[Toy museum|Toy]] || The museum contains over 800 dolls from around the world.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Dunster Doll Museum|url=http://www.dunster.org.uk/out_and_about/things_to_see_and_do/dunster_dolls_museum.php|publisher=Dunster Village Website|accessdate=26 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Dunster Working Watermill]]||[[File:Dunster mill.jpg|100px]] ||[[Dunster]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1825|-3.4459|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Dunster Working Watermill}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Mill || This [[watermill]] in the grounds of [[Dunster Castle]], built around 1780 and restored to working order in 1979, is on the site of a mill mentioned in the [[Domesday Book]]. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Castle Mill and attached gateway and gates | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=264700 | accessdate=7 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is operated by the National Trust.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Dunster Working Watermill|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-dunsterworkingwatermill|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=26 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[East Somerset Railway]] ||[[File:CranmoreStation.jpg|100px]] ||[[Cranmore, Somerset|Cranmore]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1902|-2.4801|type:landmark_region:GB|name=East Somerset Railway}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Railway || A heritage railway and museum,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=East Somerset Railway|url=http://www.eastsomersetrailway.com/|publisher=East Somerset Railway|accessdate=26 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; located at the old station, it contains a [[red telephone box]] that incorporates a stamp machine and post box (one of only 50 made),&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.eastsomersetrailway.com/page.php?pid=16|title=Cranmore Station|publisher=East Somerset Railway|accessdate=12 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; produced around 1927. Opposite the platform, there is a [[signal box]] dating from 1904, which is in the standard [[Great Western Railway]] pattern of the period.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Cranmore Station|url=http://www.eastsomersetrailway.com/page.php?pid=16|publisher=East Somerset Railway|accessdate=2 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Farleigh Hungerford Castle]]||[[File:Farleigh Hungerford Castle gate.JPG|100px]] ||[[Farleigh Hungerford]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3172|-2.2847|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Farleigh Hungerford Castle}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Historic house || Built around 1370, it has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building and [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]].&lt;ref name=&quot;IoEcastle&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=267186|title=Farleigh Hungerford Castle|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=29 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is operated by English Heritage. A medieval priest's house, chapel and castle house remain.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Farleigh Hungerford Castle|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/farleigh-hungerford-castle/|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Fashion Museum, Bath]]||[[File:Fashion Museum and Assembly Rooms Bath.jpg|100px]] || [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3862|-2.3624|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Fashion Museum, Bath}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Textile || Previously known as the Museum of Costume, it is housed in the [[Bath Assembly Rooms|Assembly Rooms]]. The collection was started by [[Doris Langley Moore]], who gave her collection to the city of Bath in 1963.&lt;ref name=&quot;24hrfashion&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Fashion Museum|url=http://www.fashionmuseum.co.uk/|publisher=Bath and North East Somerset|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The collection focuses on [[fashion]]able dress for men, women and children from the late 16th&amp;nbsp;century to the present day and has more than 30,000&amp;nbsp;objects in its collection.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000051 |title=Fashion museum, Bath |accessdate=5 November 2007 |format= |work=24 hour museum }}&lt;/ref&gt; Every year since its creation in 1963, an independent fashion expert has been asked to select a dress for entry into this part of the collection. The designers whose work is represented include [[Mary Quant]], [[John Bates (designer)|John Bates]], [[Ossie Clark]], [[Jean Muir]], [[Giorgio Armani]], [[John Galliano]], [[Ralph Lauren]], [[Alexander McQueen]], [[Donatella Versace]] and [[Alber Elbaz]].&lt;ref name=&quot;24hrfashion&quot;/&gt;
|-
| [[Fleet Air Arm Museum]]||[[File:Fleet Air Arm Museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[RNAS Yeovilton (HMS Heron)|RNAS Yeovilton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0136|-2.6448|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Fleet Air Arm Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || [[Aviation museum|Aviation]] || The museum has an extensive collection of military and civilian aircraft, as well as models of [[Royal Navy]] ships, especially [[aircraft carriers]]. There are some interactive displays. It is located by [[RNAS Yeovilton]], and the museum has viewing areas where visitors can watch military aircraft (especially helicopters) take off and land. There are 94 aircraft in the museum's collection.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Fleet Air Arm Museum|url=http://www.fleetairarm.com/|publisher=Fleet Air Arm Museum|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Frome Museum]]||[[File:North Parade Frome1.JPG|100px]] || [[Frome]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2328|-2.3191|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Frome Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Local || A collection of local history, this museum has a particularly important collection of artefacts from the [[bronze]] foundry of {{nowrap|J. W. Singer}}.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Frome Museum|url=http://www.fromemuseum.org/|publisher=Frome Museum|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; A display is devoted to the Butler and Tanner printing works in the town, including an old printing press. Another display exhibits photographs, diagrams, plans and tools from [[James Fussell]]'s [[Old Ironstone Works, Mells|Ironworks]] of [[Mells, Somerset|Mells]]. Other displays show items from Bussman Cooper (later Beswicks), the [[Marston Bigot#House|Marston House]] Fire Engine, local blacksmithing, a chemist shop from Bath Street and a collection of Victorian and later costumes.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.fromemuseum.org/collection.htm|title=Collection|publisher=Frome Museum|accessdate=6 February 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[Italianate]] building was built as a Literary and Scientific Institute in 1865. It is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=266268|title=Literary and Scientific Institute|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=6 February 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Fyne Court]]||[[File:Fynecourt.jpg|100px]] ||[[Broomfield, Somerset|Broomfield]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0806|-3.1143|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Fyne Court}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Historic house || A National Trust-owned [[nature reserve]] and [[visitor centre]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Fyne Court|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-fynecourt/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; Fyne Court once belonged to the pioneering 19th-century electrician [[Andrew Crosse]], whose family had owned the house from its construction.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book |title=Somerset: The complete guide |last=Bush |first=Robin |authorlink=Robin Bush (historian) |coauthors= |year=1994 |publisher=Dovecote Press |location=Wimborne, Dorset |isbn=1874336261 |url= |page=46 }}&lt;/ref&gt; It burnt down in 1898.&lt;ref name=&quot;waite&quot;&gt;{{cite book |title=Portrait of the Quantocks |last=Waite |first=Vincent |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1964 |publisher=Robert Hale|page=38 |location=London |isbn=0709111584 |pages= }}&lt;/ref&gt; Fyne Court has been in the ownership of the National Trust since 1967. The [[Quantock Hills]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] Service have their headquarters in the grounds.
|-
| [[Gants Mill]]||[[File:Gants Mill.jpg|100px]] ||[[Pitcombe]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1064|-2.4669|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Gants Mill}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Mill || Much of the current mill was built in 1810 but it includes parts of the 18th-century building and possibly some material from earlier mills. It is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=434673|title=Gants Mill|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=31 October 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://webapp1.somerset.gov.uk/her/details.asp?prn=50955|title=Gants Mill|work=Somerset Historic Environment Record|publisher=Somerset County Council|accessdate=31 October 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; Most of the machinery, including the grindstones, conveyors, sack hoist and grain bins, dates from 1888, and is still used for grinding animal feed and occasionally whole wheat flour.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Gants Mill|url=http://www.gantsmill.co.uk/|publisher=Gants Mill|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The [[South Somerset Hydropower Group]] was begun in 2001 and the first turbine, at Gants Mill, was commissioned in 2003.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.gantsmill.co.uk/hydropower.htm|title=Hydropower|publisher=Gants Mill|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://powerfromthelandscape.co.uk/how-to-develop-a-micro-hydro-scheme/case-studies|title=Case studies|publisher=Power from the landscape|accessdate=8 November 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The water garden includes seasonal displays of iris, roses, delphiniums, day lilies, clematis, and dahlias.
|-
| [[Glastonbury Abbey]]||align=center |[[File:Glastonbury Abbey Lady Chapel.JPG|80px]] ||[[Glastonbury]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1456|-2.7144|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Glastonbury Abbey}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Living || There are portrayals of 14th-century monks, kitchen maids, pilgrims, and [[King Arthur]]'s court, as well as exhibits of the history and artefacts of the abbey.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Glastonbury Abbey|url=http://www.glastonburyabbey.com/|publisher=Glastonbury Abbey|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The ruins of the great church, along with the Lady Chapel, have Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed status,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Glastonbury Abbey | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=265970 | accessdate=11 November 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt; and are set in {{convert|36|acre|m2}} of parkland that is open to the public. It is approached by the Abbey Gatehouse, which was built in the mid-14th&amp;nbsp;century and completely restored in 1810.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=265968|title=Abbey Gatehouse, including the porters' lodge|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=19 August 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[The Tribunal, Glastonbury|Glastonbury Lake Village Museum]]||align=center |[[File:Glastonbury Tribunal 2.jpg|80px]] ||[[Glastonbury]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1462|-2.7098|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Glastonbury Lake Village Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Archaeology || The Tribunal was built in the 15th&amp;nbsp;century as a merchant's house. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=265920|title=The Tribunal |work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=20 August 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; It now houses the Glastonbury Lake Village Museum, containing [[British Iron Age|Iron Age]] possessions and works of art from the [[Glastonbury Lake Village]], which were preserved in almost perfect condition in the peat after the village was abandoned. The museum is run by the Glastonbury Antiquarian Society.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.glastonburyantiquarians.org/site/index.php|title=Glastonbury Antiquarian Society|publisher=Glastonbury Antiquarian Society|accessdate=22 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Glastonbury Lake Village|url=http://www.glastonburyantiquarians.org/site/index.php?page_id=54|publisher=Glastonbury Antiquarians|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Haynes Motor Museum]]||[[File:Haynes Bricklin.jpg|100px]] ||[[Sparkford]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0355|-2.5656|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Haynes Motor Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || [[Transport museum|Automobile]] || The museum contains over 400&amp;nbsp;cars and [[motorcycles]] and a collection of other [[automobilia]]. The museum, which was established in 1985, is an Educational [[charitable trust|Charitable Trust]] chaired by John Haynes [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], of Haynes Publishing Group, the company which publishes the [[Haynes Manuals]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Haynes Motor Museum|url=http://www.haynesmotormuseum.com/home/index.html|publisher=Haynes Motor Museum|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[The Helicopter Museum (Weston)|Helicopter Museum]]||[[File:WestonHelicopterMuseum.jpg|100px]] ||[[Weston-super-Mare]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3395|-2.9303|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Helicopter Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || [[Aviation museum|Aviation]] || The museum houses a collection of more than 80&amp;nbsp;[[helicopter]]s and [[autogyro]]s from around the world, both civilian and military, particularly from the [[Soviet Union]] and [[Eastern Bloc]]. Examples include the [[Kamov Ka-26|Kamov Ka-26 Hoodlum]] and the [[Mi-24 Hind]], as well as more modern machines such as the [[EH-101]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=The Helicopter Museum|url=http://www.helicoptermuseum.co.uk/|publisher=The Helicopter Museum|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Herschel Museum of Astronomy]] ||align=center |[[File:Herschel Museum Bath 2005.jpg|80px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3825|-2.3667|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Herschel Museum of Astronomy}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Science || The museum is dedicated to the life and works of astronomer [[William Herschel]] and his sister [[Caroline Herschel]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Herschel Museum of Astronomy|url=http://www.bath-preservation-trust.org.uk/?id=8|publisher=[[Bath Preservation Trust]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is situated in the Herschels' former home, which has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Nos 18–19 New King Street | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=443114 | accessdate=30 September 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; Many astronomical and musical artefacts are on display, including a replica of the telescope with which Herschel discovered Uranus, and a full-scale reproduction of a lamp micrometer.
|-
| [[Holburne Museum of Art]] ||[[File:Holbornemuseum.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3857|-2.3511|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Holburne Museum of Art}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Art || Part of the [[University of Bath]], the building was originally designed as the Sydney Hotel, and was built by [[Charles Harcourt Masters]] in 1795–6. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Holburne of Menstrie Museum | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=443742 | accessdate=27 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; It houses the art collection formed by [[William Holburne|Sir William Holburne]] including [[silver-gilt]], [[Old Master]] paintings, Italian [[Bronze sculpture|bronzes]] such as the [[Susioni]] once owned by [[King Louis XIV]], [[maiolica]], [[porcelain]], glass, furniture and [[portrait miniatures]]. These have been added to with examples of landscapes by [[Francesco Guardi]] and [[J. M. W. Turner]], and portraits by [[George Stubbs]], [[Allan Ramsay (artist)|Allan Ramsay]], [[Johann Zoffany]] and [[Thomas Gainsborough]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Holbourne Museum of Art|url=http://www.bath.ac.uk/holburne/|publisher=Bath University|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Ilchester Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Ilchester]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0016|-2.6838|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ilchester Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || The museum is housed in Ilchester Town Hall,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Ilchester Museum|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6596|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; which is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Town Hall|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=263450|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It contains exhibits showing the history of the town from the [[Iron Age]] and [[Roman Britain|Roman]] periods, when it was known as [[Lindinis]], to the present day.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Ilchester Museum|url=http://www.ilchesterparishcouncil.gov.uk/Core/IlchesterPC/Pages/Museum_3.aspx|publisher=Ilchester Parish Council|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; They include the town's 13th-century [[Ceremonial mace|mace]] or [[staff of office]], bearing the insignia of [[Richard I]], which is the oldest staff of office in England.&lt;ref name=&quot;curio&quot;&gt;{{cite book |title=Curiosities of Somerset |last=Leete-Hodge |first=Lornie |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1985 |publisher=Bossiney Books |location=Bodmin |isbn=0906456983 |page=73 }}&lt;/ref&gt; The collection also includes a full set of [[Maundy Money]], acquired in 1995.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Ilchester Museum|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/am11996|publisher= [[Culture24]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Jane Austen Centre]] ||[[File:Jane Austen Centre.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3851|-2.3633|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Jane Austen Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Biographical || The museum concentrates on author [[Jane Austen]]'s family and her life in Bath.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Jane Austen Centre|url=http://www.janeausten.co.uk/|publisher=Jane Austen Centre|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[King John's Hunting Lodge]]||[[File:King John's Hunting Lodge, Axbridge.jpg|100px]] ||[[Axbridge]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.287167|-2.81851|type:landmark_region:GB|name=King John's Hunting Lodge}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, this is an early Tudor timber-framed wool merchant's house with local history exhibits.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=King John's Hunting Lodge|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-kingjohnshuntinglodge/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is run as a local history museum by Axbridge and District Museum Trust, in co-operation with [[Sedgemoor|Sedgemoor District Council]], Somerset County Museums Service and Axbridge Archaeological and Local History Society, and is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=King John's Hunting Lodge | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=268654 | accessdate=9 May 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Lambretta Scooter Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Weston-super-Mare]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3485|-2.97|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lambretta Scooter Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || [[Transport museum|Transportation]] || The museum houses a total of 61&amp;nbsp;[[Lambretta]] models – at least one from each year between October 1947 and May 1971.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Lambetta Scooter Museum|url=http://www.scooterproducts.com/catalog.php?category=Lambretta%20Museum|publisher=Scooterproducts|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The private collection ranges from three model &quot;A&quot;s, first produced in 1947, to Lambro three wheelers, Lambretta mopeds, sales leaflets, accessories, posters, magazines, manuals, toys, models, signs, and promotional material. The museum was re-opened on 9 August 2008, after refurbishment of it and its exhibits.
|-
| [[Langport and River Parrett Visitor Centre]] ||align=center |–||[[Langport]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0351|-2.8359|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Langport and River Parrett Visitor Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || Situated by Bow Bridge over the [[River Parrett]], the Langport Visitor Centre has displays and exhibitions related to local history, industry and the natural history of the river. It is also a central point for information about the [[River Parrett Trail]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Langport|url=http://www.iknow-somerset.co.uk/tourist_information/central_somerset/south_west/langport_somerset.htm|publisher=I know Somerset|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Langport &amp; River Parrett Visitor Centre|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=688|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; a [[long-distance footpath]], following the route of the River Parrett. The trail, which is {{convert|50|mi|km}} long,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=River Parrett Trail|url=http://www.ldwa.org.uk/ldp/members/show_path.php?path_name=River+Parrett+Trail|publisher=Long distance walkers association|accessdate=3 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=The River Parrettt Trail|url=http://www.visitsouthsomerset.com/index.jsp?articleid=12641|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=3 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; runs from [[Chedington]] in [[Dorset]] to the mouth of the river in [[Bridgwater Bay]], where it joins the [[West Somerset Coast Path]].
|-
| [[Lytes Cary|Lytes Cary Manor]]||[[File:Lytes Cary 2009 East front from beyond haha.JPG|100px]] ||[[Charlton Mackrell]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0358|-2.6677|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Lytes Cary Manor}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Historic house || The property, owned by the National Trust, has parts dating to the 14th&amp;nbsp;century, with other sections dating to the 15th, 16th, 18th, and 20th centuries.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Lytes Cary|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-lytescarymanor/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The house is listed as Grade&amp;nbsp;I.&lt;ref name=&quot;IoE house&quot;&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=262836|title=Lytes Cary|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=28 April 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; The chapel predates the existing house, and functioned as a [[chantry]] chapel, where masses could be said for the souls of the family, both living and dead. The gardens are listed as Grade&amp;nbsp;II on the [[National Register of Historic Parks and Gardens|English Heritage Register of Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.parksandgardens.ac.uk/component/option,com_parksandgardens/task,site/id,2180/tab,description/Itemid,293/|title=Lytes Cary, Somerton, England|work=Parks and Gardens UK.|publisher= Association of Gardens Trusts and the University of York|accessdate=28 April 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Market House Museum]]||[[File:Market House Museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Watchet]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1795|-3.3242|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Market House Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Local || The building was constructed in 1820 on the site of the previous market house, which had been demolished in 1805. It was converted into a museum in 1979. It is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=264619|title= The Market House|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=26 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; housing a collection of exhibits about the natural history of Watchet and the surrounding area. The focus is on nautical and maritime history of the port.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.watchettowncouncil.org/things_to_see.php|title=Market House Museum – Corner of Market St. and the Esplanade|publisher=Watchet Town Council|accessdate=26 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum's collection includes artefacts from archaeology, coins and medals, land and maritime transport, natural sciences, science and technology and social history.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000146|title=Watchet Market House Museum|publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=26 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Montacute House]]||[[File:Montacute House front Apr 2002.JPG|100px]] ||[[Montacute]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9524|-2.716|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Montacute House}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, the museum includes an [[Elizabethan]] mansion with 16th-century furniture and textiles, a Long Gallery with over 60 [[Tudor dynasty|Tudor]] and Elizabethan portraits from the [[National Portrait Gallery (London)|National Portrait Gallery]] collection and gardens.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Montacute House|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-montacute.htm|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Montacute House | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=434945|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | accessdate=5 November 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; and [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://webapp1.somerset.gov.uk/her/details.asp?prn=56223|title=Montacute House, The Borough (North side, off), Montacute|work=Somerset Historic Environment Record|publisher=Somerset County Council|accessdate=7 November 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; and was visited by 110,529 people in 2009.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.alva.org.uk/visitor_statistics/ |title=Visits made in 2009 |accessdate=17 May 2010 |work=Association of Leading Visitor Attractions }}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Montacute Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Montacute]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9493|-2.7149|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Montacute Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Media || The museum has a collection of toys, games and jigsaws related to radio and TV programmes.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Montacute museum|url=http://www.montacutemuseum.co.uk/Default.aspx?ContentID=2|publisher=Montacute museum|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; There are also over 500 radios from vintage wirelesses to novelty transistors, radiograms and televisions.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Montacute TV Radio &amp; Toy Museum|url=http://search.visitbritain.com/en-IN/Details.aspx?ContentID=631872|publisher=Visit Britain|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Muchelney Abbey]]||[[File:Muchelney Parish church, abbey foreground ruins.jpg|100px]] ||[[Muchelney]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0167|-2.8203|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Muchelney Abbey}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Religious || Operated by English Heritage, it comprises the remains and [[Foundation (architecture)|foundations]] of a medieval [[Benedictine]] [[abbey]], the site of an earlier [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] abbey, and an early [[Tudor Style architecture|Tudor]] house dating from the 16th&amp;nbsp;century, which was formerly the lodgings of the resident [[abbot]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=The Abbot's House, Muchelney Abbey | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=263283 | accessdate=25 September 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Mulchelney Abbey|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/muchelney-abbey/|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Museum of Bath at Work]] ||[[File:Museum of Bath at Work.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3889|-2.3629|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Museum of Bath at Work}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Local || This museum was established in 1978 to present the commercial development of Bath over the last 2,000 years. The main exhibit is the reconstruction of an engineering and mineral water manufacturing business set up by Victorian entrepreneur Jonathan Bowler in 1864. The museum's displays, occupying four floors, also cover local history, including industry and trades, and detail the city's development as a retailing and manufacturing centre, and as a tourist and health resort.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum of Bath at Work|url=http://www.bathatwork.co.uk/index.html|publisher=Museum of Bath at Work|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Museum of East Asian Art]] ||align=center |– ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3794|-2.367|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Museum of East Asian Art}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Art || The restored [[Georgian architecture|Georgian]] house contains a collection of [[Ceramic art|ceramics]], [[jade]]s, [[bronzes]] and [[bamboo]] carvings from [[China]], [[Japan]], [[Korea]] and [[Southeast Asia]]. In total there are almost 2,000 objects, ranging in date from ''c.''&amp;nbsp;5000 BC to the present day.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bath.ac.uk/news/2007/2/21/gulp-laxton.html |title=Free public lecture: Discover Bath’s Museum of East Asian Art |accessdate=28 October 2007 |work=University of Bath }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum of East Asian Art|url=http://www.meaa.org.uk/|publisher=Museum of East Asian Art|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Somerset County Museum|Museum of Somerset]]||[[File:SomersetMuseum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Taunton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0191|-3.1|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Museum of Somerset}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Multiple || Located in [[Taunton Castle]], the museum contains a collection of toys and dolls, [[sculpture]], [[natural history]], [[fossil]]s, fine [[Silver (household)|silver]] and [[pottery]], as well as a collection of [[archaeological]] items, including the mosaic found at the [[Low Ham Roman Villa]]. One of the exhibits is the [[Labarum|''Chi-Rho'']] [[amulet]] found in [[Shepton Mallet]], held to be among the earliest evidence of [[Christianity]] in England.&lt;ref name=&quot;leach&quot;&gt;{{cite book|last=Leach|first=Peter|title=Shepton Mallet: Romano-Britons and Early Christians in Somerset|publisher=Birmingham University Field Archeology Unit|location=Birmingham|year=1991|page=24|isbn=0704411296}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/2008/sep/19/archaeology.anglicanism|title='Roman' amulet adopted by archbishop is a fake|last=Morris|first=Steven|date=2008-09-19|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Newspapers|accessdate=19 September 2008 | location=London}}&lt;/ref&gt; In October 2007, plans for a £6.5&amp;nbsp;million improvement to the museum and the castle were submitted by [[Somerset County Council]] to the [[Heritage Lottery Fund]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news |first=Phil |last=Hill |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Plans go in for £6.5million museum |url=http://www.somersetcountygazette.co.uk/news/sgnewstaunton/display.var.1779924.0.plans_go_in_for_6_5million_museum.php |work=Somerset County Gazette |publisher= |date=2007-10-24 |accessdate=29 October 2007 }}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum closed to the public on 18 April 2008 for a two-year refit, and is planned to re-open in 2011 as the Museum of Somerset.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum of Somerset|url=http://www.somerset.gov.uk/irj/public/services/directory/service?rid=/guid/4096f99f-0437-2c10-9ab0-c4728e907b47|publisher=Somerset County Council|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Museum of South Somerset]] ||[[File:Museum of South Somerset.jpg|100px]] ||[[Yeovil]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9394|-2.6348|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Museum of South Somerset}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || Based in the former coach house to Hendford Manor, the museum contains displays of local history and geology, particularly local industries such as leather and glove-making, flax and hemp production, stone working, engineering and newspaper printing. The displays cover various stages of the history of the area from the prehistory and the Roman period through to the agricultural and industrial revolutions, and include a reconstructed Roman dining room and kitchen with mosaics recreated from excavations of local villas at Westland, [[Lufton]], and [[Ilchester]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=South Somerset Museum|url=http://southsomersetmuseums.org.uk/|publisher=South Somerset Museum|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum of South Somerset|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000077|publisher=[[Culture24]]|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum of South Somerset|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=702|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Royal Crescent#Current use|No. 1 Royal Crescent]] ||[[File:Royal.crescent.bath.arp.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3868|-2.3671|type:landmark_region:GB|name=No.1 Royal Crescent}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Historic house || Number 1 [[Royal Crescent]] was built between 1767 and 1774 by [[John Wood the Younger]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=No 1 Royal Crescent|url=http://www.bath-preservation-trust.org.uk/?id=3|publisher=[[Bath Preservation Trust]]|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is now a museum, maintained by the [[Bath Preservation Trust]], illustrating how wealthy owners of the [[Georgian era|Georgian]] period might have furnished such a house.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=No 1 Royal Crescent | work=Images of England | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=447275 | accessdate=12 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It was purchased in 1967 by Major Bernard Cayzer and donated to the trust along with funds to restore and furnish it.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book|last=Lowndes|first=William|title=The Royal Crescent in Bath|pages=24–25|publisher=Redcliffe Press|year=1981|isbn=978-0905459349}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[North Somerset Museum]]||align=center |[[File:North Somerset Museum entrance.jpg|80px]] ||[[Weston-super-Mare]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3485|-2.97|type:landmark_region:GB|name=North Somerset Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || Local || The collection includes archaeological exhibits, including those from Worlebury [[Iron Age]] [[hill fort]]. Social history is also covered, with a particular focus on local industries such as Royal Potteries,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/mw1515|title=North Somerset Museum|publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=22 March 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; seaside holidays, costume and domestic life.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.n-somerset.gov.uk/Leisure/Museum/Galleries/|title=Galleries|work=North Somerset Museum|publisher=North Somerset Council|accessdate=22 March 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; There is also a replica of a 19th-century chemist shop, along with exhibits that explore life on the Home Front for the people of North Somerset during the Second World War, from [[Strategic bombing|air-raids]] to vegetable plots, as well as secret weapons developed on Birnbeck Island.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.visitsomerset.co.uk/site/things-to-do/attractions/north-somerset-museum-p138713|title=North Somerset Museum|publisher=Visit Somerset|accessdate=22 March 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Museum|url=http://www.n-somerset.gov.uk/Leisure/Museum/|publisher=North Somerset Council|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Porlock Museum]]||[[File:Dovery Manor, Porlock, Somerset - geograph.org.uk - 113293.jpg|100px]] ||[[Porlock]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2088|-3.5956|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Porlock Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Local || The building was built as the Dovery [[Manor house]] in the late 15th&amp;nbsp;century and extended in the 17th&amp;nbsp;century. In 1895 the building was restored by Edmund Buckle for [[Charles Chadwyck-Healey|Sir Charles Chadwyck-Healey]]. It is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Doverhay Reading Room and cottage abutting north end|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=265461|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum has a collection of artefacts, photographs, press cuttings, paintings and displays of local interest, particularly relating to [[Porlock Hill]] on the [[A39 road|A39]].&lt;ref name=&quot;everythingexmoor&quot;&gt;{{cite web|title=Doverhay Manor Museum |url=http://www.everythingexmoor.org.uk/exmoor-encyclopedia/contents-list/36-d/319-doverhay-manor-museum.html|publisher=Everything Exmoor|accessdate=31 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; At the rear of the building a herb garden is being restored with plants grown for medicinal and culinary use when the manor was built.&lt;ref name=&quot;everythingexmoor&quot;/&gt;
|-
| [[The Priest's House, Muchelney|Priest's House]]||[[File:Priesthouse.jpg|100px]] ||[[Muchelney]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0211|-2.8152|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Priest's House}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Religious || Now operated by the National Trust, this house was built by [[Muchelney Abbey]] in 1308 for the parish priest, and incorporates a Gothic doorway, tracery windows and a 15th-century fireplace. The building was said to be &quot;ruinous&quot; in 1608. It was used by the vicar or curate until around 1840, when the house was used as a cellar and later as a school, and in the late 19th&amp;nbsp;century it was rented by a farmer. The building was acquired by the [[British National Trust]] in 1911, who rent it to a tenant who provides limited access to the public. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title= The Priest's house | work=[[Images of England]] |publisher=[[English Heritage]]| url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=263287 | accessdate=30 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Priest's House|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-priestshousemuchelney/|publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]]|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Radstock Museum]]||[[File:Radstock museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Radstock]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2936|-2.4486|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Radstock Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Multiple || Many of the exhibits relate to the now-disused local [[Somerset coalfield]] and [[geology]]. Other displays show aspects of local history, including the school and shops, and industries such as [[agriculture]], a [[forge]], and a [[carpenter]]'s shop. Artefacts and memorabilia of the [[Somerset Coal Canal]], [[Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway|Somerset and Dorset]] and [[Great Western Railway]]s are also on display. There is also a Victorian classroom and displays relating to [[John Wesley]] and [[Horatio Nelson Ward]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Radstock Museum|url=http://www.radstockmuseum.co.uk/|publisher=Radstock Museum|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum is housed in the restored and converted Victorian Market Hall, a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building dating from 1897.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title= Radstock Market Hall | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=31958 | accessdate=10 December 2006}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Roman Baths (Bath)|Roman Baths]] ||[[File:Roman Baths in Bath Spa, England - July 2006.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3809|-2.3595|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Roman Baths}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Archaeology || This is a well-preserved [[Roman Britain|Roman]] site for public bathing.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Roman Baths|url=http://www.romanbaths.co.uk/|publisher=Bath and North East Somerset Council|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Roman Baths themselves are below the modern street level. There are four main features: the Sacred Spring, the Roman Temple, the Roman Bath House and the Museum, which holds finds from Roman Bath. The buildings above street level date from the 19th&amp;nbsp;century.
|-
| [[Sally Lunn's House]] ||[[File:Sally Lunns house.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3815|-2.3599|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Sally Lunn's House}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Historic house || This tea and eating house, with a period kitchen, dates from the 17th&amp;nbsp;century house, and is where the [[Sally Lunn bun]] originated.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Sally Lunns House|url=http://www.sallylunns.co.uk/home,intro.htm|publisher=Sally Lunns House|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[The Shoe Museum|Shoe Museum]]||[[File:Shoe Museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Street, Somerset|Street]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.129|-2.7394|type:landmark_region:GB|name=The Shoe Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Industry || The museum gives the history of the ''[[C&amp;J Clark]]'' shoe manufacturer, and exhibits shoes dating from the [[Roman Britain|Roman]] era to the present day.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Shoe Museum|url=http://www.somersettouristguide.com/Street/The_Shoe_Museum_1011.asp|publisher=Somerset Tourist Guide|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; There is also a display of machinery used in footwear production,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.information-britain.co.uk/showPlace.cfm?Place_ID=2461|title=Shoe Museum|publisher=Information Britain|accessdate=12 July 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; a selection of shop display showcards from the 1930s, 1950s, and 1960s,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.nothingtoseehere.net/2007/06/the_shoe_museum_street.html|title=The Shoe Museum, Street|publisher=Nothing to see here|accessdate=12 July 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; and television advertisements.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.somersettouristguide.com/Street/The_Shoe_Museum_1011.asp|title=The Shoe Museum|publisher=Somerset Tourist Guide|accessdate=12 July 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Midsomer Norton railway station#Somerset and Dorset Railway Heritage Centre|Somerset and Dorset Railway Heritage Centre]] ||[[File:Midsomernortonstation.jpg|100px]] ||[[Midsomer Norton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2811|-2.4833|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset and Dorset Railway Heritage Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Railway || Based at [[Midsomer Norton railway station]], the site includes restored station buildings, a signalbox and a goods shed. The museum is located in an old stable block. It has almost a quarter of a mile of railway and a diesel locomotive.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=The S&amp;D Mendip Mainline Project|url=http://www.sdjr.co.uk/pages/general.html|publisher=Somerset &amp; Dorset Railway Heritage Trust|accessdate=5 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Washford railway station#Somerset and Dorset Railway Trust Museum|Somerset and Dorset Railway Trust Museum]] ||[[File:Southern Railway Wagons at Washford railway station.jpg|100px]] ||[[Washford]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1617|-3.3681|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset and Dorset Railway Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Railway || The museum contains relics of the [[Somerset and Dorset Joint Railway]] (S&amp;DJR), including station nameboards, lamps, tools, signalling equipment, tickets, photographs, handbills, rolling stock and steam locomotives.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=The Museum|url=http://www.sdrt.org.uk/resources/museum/index.htm|publisher=Somerset and Dorset Railway Trust|accessdate=7 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Trust's [[Peckett and Sons]] [[0-4-0]]ST No. 1788 &quot;Kilmersdon&quot; is normally based here. Next to the original stone station building of 1874 is a much smaller wooden building, which was originally the [[Great Western Railway]]'s [[signal box]]. This structure now houses a recreation of the interior of the S&amp;DJR signal-box at {{stnlnk|Midford}}. A second signal box is used as part of a signalling display in the yard, and was formerly used on the S&amp;DJR at {{stnlnk|Burnham-on-Sea}}.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book| last = Oakley| first = Mike| title = Somerset Railway Stations| publisher = Redcliffe Press| year = 2006| location = Bristol| isbn = 1-904537-54-5| pages = 121–122 }}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Somerset Brick and Tile Museum]]||[[File:Brick and tile factory.jpg|100px]] ||[[Bridgwater]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1285|-2.9938|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset Brick and Tile Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Industry || The museum is dedicated to the brick and tile industry of Somerset.
