It incorporates the last surviving &quot;pinnacle kiln&quot; in Bridgwater, which dates from the 19th&amp;nbsp;century, and has been designated as a [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]] and Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Brick kiln East Quay | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=373878 | accessdate=30 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; The kiln was one of six at the former Barham Brothers' Yard at East Quay. It was last fired in 1965, the year that the works closed. Demonstrated inside are the tools, methods and processes involved in making a variety of bricks, tiles, and terracotta plaques.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.culture24.org.uk/am11844 Somerset Brick and Tile Museum, Bridgwater] entry on [[Culture24]]. Retrieved 9 December 2009.&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Somerset Cricket Museum]]||[[File:Somerset cricket museum.jpg|100px]] ||[[Taunton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0189|-3.0989|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset Cricket Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Sports || The building, which is within the confines of the [[County Ground, Taunton|County Ground]], is the Old Priory Barn, a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Priory Barn|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=269856|accessdate=3 July 2010|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is the only surviving building of the [[Augustinian]] [[Taunton Priory]], which was founded about 1115.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite book | author = Thomas Hugo | year = 1860 | title = The History of Taunton Priory in the County of Somerset. | url=http://books.google.com/?id=R68LAAAAYAAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover&amp;dq=isbn%3A9781437375350&amp;q |page=4 |publisher = J. R. Smith, London | isbn=978-1437375350 }}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref name=&quot;gathercole&quot;&gt;{{cite web|last=Gathercole|first=Clare|title=Taunton|url=http://www1.somerset.gov.uk/archives/hes/downloads/EUS_TauntonText.pdf|work=Extensive urban archeological surveys|publisher=Somerset County Council| accessdate=19 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; In 1989 the museum was opened to the public,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Somerset Cricket Museum celebrates 21 year! |url=http://www.somersetcountycc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Museum/0,,11333,00.html |date=26 April 2010 |publisher=Somerset County Cricket Club| accessdate=28 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; with exhibits and displays covering the cricket club's history including [[Test cricket|Test match]] players such as [[Ian Botham]] and [[Marcus Trescothick]]. It also has a section devoted to the [[England women's cricket team]],&lt;ref&gt;{{cite news|title=The cricket museum|url=http://www.thisissomerset.co.uk/news/Somerset-Places-cricket-museum/article-1211002-detail/article.html|accessdate=27 May 2010|newspaper=Somerset Guardian}}&lt;/ref&gt; and a collection of [[I Zingari|I&amp;nbsp;Zingari]] memorabilia.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://somersetcricketmuseum.co.uk/zingari.html |title=I Zingari |publisher=Somerset Cricket Museum |accessdate=29 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Somerset Military Museum]]||[[File:SomersetMuseum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Taunton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0191|-3.1|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset Military Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || [[Regimental museum|Military]] || This presents the history and memorabilia of several of the area's regiments, and is located within the [[Somerset County Museum|Museum of Somerset]] at [[Taunton Castle]]. The museum includes [[medals]], [[uniforms]] and other historical artefacts related to the local regiments: [[Somerset Light Infantry]] (Prince Albert's), [[Somerset and Cornwall Light Infantry]], [[West Somerset Yeomanry]], [[North Somerset Yeomanry]], [[Somerset Militia]], Rifle Volunteers and Territorials, [[The Light Infantry]] and its successor regiment, [[The Rifles]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Somerset Military Museum|url=http://www.sommilmuseum.org.uk/|publisher=Somerset Military Museum|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Somerset Rural Life Museum]]||[[File:Abbey Tithe Barn, Glastonbury 1.JPG|100px]] ||[[Glastonbury]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1485|-2.714|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Somerset Rural Life Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Rural || A museum of the social and agricultural history of Somerset, housed in buildings surrounding a 14th-century [[barn]] once belonging to [[Glastonbury Abbey]], and once used as a [[tithe barn]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.glastonbury.com/abbey.php|title=Glastonbury Abbey|publisher=Glastonbury Abbey|accessdate=2 November 2008}}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Abbey Tithe Barn, including attached wall to east | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=265895 | accessdate=29 September 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is a [[Scheduled Ancient Monument]]. The barn and courtyard contain displays of farm machinery from the [[Victorian era|Victorian]] or early 20th-century period.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Somerset Rural Life Museum|url=http://www.somerset.gov.uk/irj/public/services/directory/service?rid=/guid/e056fae3-0437-2c10-4999-e5403d304e93|publisher=Somerset County Council|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Stembridge Mill, High Ham|Stembridge Tower Mill]] ||[[File:StembridgeTowerMill(PatrickMackie)Aug2006.jpg|100px]] ||[[High Ham]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0765|-2.8203|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Stembridge Tower Mill}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Mill || Operated by the National Trust, it is the last remaining [[thatched]] [[windmill]] in England and the last survivor of five windmills that once existed in the area.&lt;ref name=&quot;curio&quot;&gt;{{cite book |title=Curiosities of Somerset |last=Leete-Hodge |first=Lornie |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1985 |publisher=Bossiney Books |location=Bodmin |isbn=0906456983 |page=84 }}&lt;/ref&gt; Constructed in 1822, the mill has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=263124 |title=Stembridge Mill |accessdate=3 March 2008 |format= |work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] }}&lt;/ref&gt; The mill is owned by the National Trust and underwent a £100,000 restoration by local craftsmen funded by the Grantscape Community Heritage Fund in 2009; it re-opened later that year.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite journal | title = The National Trust Magazine | journal = News | issue = Autumn 2009 | pages = p11}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Treasurer's House]] ||align=center |–||[[Martock]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0211|-2.8152|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Treasurer's House}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Historic house || Operated by the National Trust, this is a medieval priest's house built from Hamstone during the 13th&amp;nbsp;century, with various extensions and alterations since. The Great Hall was completed in 1293, but there is an even earlier Solar Block with an interesting wall painting.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-treasurershousemartock/ |title=Treasurer's House |accessdate=30 October 2007 |format= |work=National Trust }}&lt;/ref&gt; It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title= The Treasurer's House | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=422284 | accessdate=30 July 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Tropiquaria]]||align=center |[[File:Tropiquaria at Washford - geograph.org.uk - 67177.jpg|80px]] ||[[Watchet]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.16|-3.3483|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Tropiquaria}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Multiple || Tropiquaria includes a tropical hall with a variety of [[snake]]s and [[lizard]]s, [[caiman]] and small carnivores such as [[dwarf mongoose]]s. Outside are [[macaw]]s, [[Common agouti|agouti]]s, [[gibbon]]s, [[Wallaby|wallabies]], [[emu]]s, [[tapir]], [[ring-tailed lemur]]s, [[ruffed lemur]]s and [[meerkat]]s. The building was an [[art deco]] [[BBC]] transmitter hall built in the 1930s,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Tropiquaria Wildlife Park |url=http://www.everythingexmoor.org.uk/exmoor-encyclopedia/contents-list/53-t/995-tropiquaria-wildlife-park.html|publisher=Everything Exmoor|accessdate=11 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and it includes a museum with radios and radio memorabilia.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Tropiquaria|url=http://www.tropiquaria.co.uk/|publisher=Tropiquaria|accessdate=11 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Tyntesfield]]||align=center |[[File:Tyntesfield 1.jpg|80px]] ||[[Wraxall, Somerset|Wraxall]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.4403|-2.7135|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Tyntesfield}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[North Somerset]] || Historic house || The estate, which is owned and operated by the National Trust, includes the [[Victorian era|Victorian]] [[Gothic Revival]] house gardens. The house, which is built of [[Bath stone]], includes the servants' wing and the chapel. It was designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed building&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Servants' wing and chapel | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33585 | accessdate=18 July 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; in 1973 and has since been upgraded to Grade&amp;nbsp;I.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Tyntefield estate|url=http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/main/w-vh/w-visits/w-findaplace/w-tyntesfield/w-tyntesfield-seeanddo/w-tyntesfield-estate.htm|publisher=National Trust|accessdate=3 July 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The principal rooms include the library, drawing room, [[Billiards#English|billiard room]] and [[dining room]].
|-
| [[Victoria Art Gallery]] ||[[File:Victoriaartgalery.JPG|100px]] ||[[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3794|-2.367|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Victoria Art Gallery}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Bath and North East Somerset]] || Art || This is a free public [[art museum]] containing paintings, sculpture and decorative arts. The building was designed in 1897 by [[John McKean Brydon]], and has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=442375|title= Victoria Art Gallery and Library|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=24 September 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; The exterior of the building includes a statue of [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]], by [[A. C. Lucchesi]], and friezes of classical figures by [[G. A. Lawson]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://myweb.tiscali.co.uk/speel/place/bath.htm |title=The Victoria Art Gallery, Bath |accessdate=28 October 2007 |work=The website of Bob Speel }}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum contains over 1,500&amp;nbsp;decorative arts treasures, including a display of British oil paintings from the 17th&amp;nbsp;century to the present day, such as works by [[Thomas Gainsborough]], [[Thomas Jones Barker]] and [[Walter Sickert]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/sw000050 |title=Victoria Art Gallery, Bath |accessdate=28 October 2007 |format= |work=Culture24 }}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Watchet Boat Museum]]||[[File:Watchet Boat Museum interior.JPG|100px]] ||[[Watchet]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.1795|-3.3242|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Watchet Boat Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || [[Maritime museum|Maritime]] || The museum is housed in an old [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] goods shed, built in 1862, next to [[Watchet railway station]] on the [[Heritage railway|heritage]] [[West Somerset Railway]]. The exhibits include several types of boats found locally and associated artefacts, photographs and charts, plus nets and other items associated with their use. There is also an example of a mudhorse, a wooden sledge that is propelled across the mudflats to collect fish from nets.&lt;ref name=&quot;opencountry&quot;&gt;{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/opencountry_20080809.shtml |title=Matt Baker goes mad for mud, fish and relics in Bridgwater Bay. |accessdate=14 November 2008 |work=Open Country |publisher=BBC |date= }}&lt;/ref&gt; The museum specialises in the shallow draft [[Flatner]], a small double-ended boats with no keel, once prevalent in the [[Bridgwater Bay]] and adjacent coastal areas.
|-
| [[Wellington Museum, Somerset|Wellington Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Wellington, Somerset|Wellington]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9755|-3.2243|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wellington Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Local || This free museum focuses on firms and individuals that are or were based in Wellington, particularly those linked with the woollen industry. There are also displays on [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington]], and his association with the town.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Wellington Museum|url=http://www.wellingtonmuseum.org.uk/index.php|publisher=Wellington Museum|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Wells and Mendip Museum]]||[[File:Wells and Mendip Museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Wells]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2109|-2.6445|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wells and Mendip Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Mendip]] || Local || The museum is housed in the former Chancellors' House, which has 15th-century origins, although most of the current fabric of the building is from the 17th and 18th centuries. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=483314|title=Wells Museum|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=12 October 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; The Balch Room houses exhibits of [[geology]] and [[fossil]]s collected from the [[Mendip Hills]], many of which date from the [[Stone Age]] and [[Iron Age]]s. Other exhibits include [[lead]] [[ingot]]s from [[Roman Britain]], [[statuary]] from Wells Cathedral, and a collection of 18th-century [[Sampler (needlework)|samplers]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.wellsmuseum.org.uk/top/society.html|title=Wells Natural History and Archaeological Society|publisher=Wells Museum|accessdate=11 October 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[West Somerset Rural Life Museum and Victorian School]]||[[File:West Somerset Rural Life Museum.JPG|100px]] ||[[Allerford]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.2116|-3.5695|type:landmark_region:GB|name=West Somerset Rural Life Museum and Victorian School}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[West Somerset]] || Rural || The building was constructed in 1821 as the village school and was closed in 1981.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Allerford Museum|url=http://www.allerfordmuseum.org.uk|publisher=Allerford Museum|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is now rented from the National Trust. In 1983 it was opened as a museum, by a charitable trust,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.hornermill.co.uk/allerfordmuseum/index.html|title=Allerford Museum|work=Horner Mill web site|accessdate=6 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; with displays of artefacts from [[West Somerset]] including cookery, laundry, tradesmen's tools, and agricultural equipment.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|url=http://www.cornucopia.org.uk/html/search/verb/ListIdentifiers/set/location/1727|title=West Somerset Rural Life Museum|work=Cornucopia|publisher=Museums and Libraries Association|accessdate=5 May 2009}}&lt;/ref&gt; One room in the [[thatched]] part of the building has been retained as a [[Victorian era|Victorian]] classroom, where children can dress in original clothing, sit at original desks and write on slates.
|-
| [[West Somerset Railway]]||align=center |[[File:Museum Exhibits.JPG|80px]] ||[[Bishops Lydeard]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0541|-3.1934|type:landmark_region:GB|name=West Somerset Railway}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Railway || A [[heritage railway]] with exhibits at the [[Bishops Lydeard railway station]]. On the original platform the old [[goods shed]] has been restored and is used as a visitor centre and museum; its artefacts includes a [[Great Western Railway]] sleeping car, and the Taunton Model Railway Club's model railway layout is on display.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Bishop's Lydeard Station|url=http://www.wsr.org.uk/bl.htm|publisher=West Somerset Railway|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Westonzoyland Pumping Station Museum]]||align=center |[[File:Westonzoylandpumpingstation.jpg|80px]] ||[[Westonzoyland]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0910|-2.9443|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Westonzoyland Pumping Station Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Sedgemoor]] || Technology || The museum is housed in the first of several similar pumping stations to be built on the [[Somerset Levels]]. The main attraction is the 1861 steam engine and pump, the only one still in its original location and in working order. The museum also displays a number of other steam engines and pumps, along with a short length of [[narrow gauge railway]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Westonzoyland Engine Trust|url=http://www.wzlet.org|publisher=Westonzoyland Engine Trust|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The pump house has been Grade&amp;nbsp;II* listed&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Westonzoyland Engine Trust Old Pumping Station|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=269603|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=16 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; and is on the English Heritage [[Buildings at Risk Register]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Westonzoyland Pumping Station|url=http://risk.english-heritage.org.uk/2010.aspx?id=807&amp;rt=0&amp;pn=1&amp;st=a&amp;ctype=exact&amp;crit=Westonzoyland|work=Heritage at Risk Register|publisher=[[English Heritage]]|accessdate=16 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Willows and Wetlands Visitor Centre]]||align=center |–||[[Stoke St Gregory]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0431|-2.9356|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Willows and Wetlands Visitor Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[Taunton Deane]] || Industry || The centre offers tours of over {{convert|80|acre|ha|0|abbr=on}} of withies, willow yards and basket workshops and explains the place of willow in the history of the Levels. It features exhibits relating to [[willow]] growing and processing and basket-making and includes a video room describing willow growing and basket making; a basket museum with displays of traditional and unusual willow artefacts; the Levels and Moors Exhibition describing the history of the local countryside and its links with this traditional industry; and an environmental interpretation display highlighting the importance of water in shaping the Somerset Levels.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Willows and Wetlands Visitor Centre|url=http://www.englishwillowbaskets.co.uk/visitor_centre.htm|publisher=Willows and Wetlands Visitor Centre|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Wincanton Museum]]||align=center |–||[[Wincanton]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.0568|-2.4077|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wincanton Museum}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Local || Housed in a late 18th- or early 19th-century cottage, which is a Grade&amp;nbsp;II listed building&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Number 30 and 32 High Street|url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=416234|work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]]}}&lt;/ref&gt; owned by the [[Quakers]],&lt;ref name=&quot;westernagzette&quot;&gt;{{cite news|title=Museum to reopen after rent rise talks|url=http://www.thisisdorset.co.uk/news/Museum-reopen-rent-rise-talks/article-1944643-detail/article.html|accessdate=4 June 2010|newspaper=Western Gazette|date=2010-03-26}}&lt;/ref&gt; the museum has a collection of artefacts, documents, posters and photographs related to the social history of Wincanton and the surrounding district. There is also a replica of a [[Victorian era|Victorian]] kitchen and a collection of 19th- and 20th-century farm implements.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Wincanton Museum|url=http://www.southsomerset.gov.uk/index.jsp?articleid=6604|publisher=South Somerset Council|accessdate=4 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; A separate room is devoted to World War I and World War II, when American soldiers were stationed in the town prior to the [[D Day]] landings.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Displays|url=http://www.wincantonmuseum.org.uk/?page_id=16|publisher=Wincanton Museum|accessdate=4 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|-
| [[Woodspring Priory]]||[[File:WoodspringPrioryFront081006.jpg|100px]] ||[[Weston-super-Mare]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|51.3908|-2.945|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Woodspring Priory}}&lt;/small&gt;|| [[North Somerset]] || Religious || This is a former [[Augustinian]] [[priory]], which was founded in the early 13th-century, and dedicated to [[Thomas Becket]]. It has been designated as a Grade&amp;nbsp;I listed building.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=263898 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; It is now owned by the [[Landmark Trust]] and rented out as holiday accommodation. There is also a small museum on the site with photographs and information about the history of the priory and its renovation by the Landmark Trust.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Woodspring Priory|url=http://bookings.landmarktrust.org.uk/BuildingDetails/Overview/184/Woodspring_Priory|publisher=Landmark Trust|accessdate=16 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; The 15th-century barn,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Barn ''c.'' 50 metres north-west of Priory Church | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33315 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; east cloister wall,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=East cloister wall | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33312 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; farmhouse range,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Farmhouse range | work=[[Images of England]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33306 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; gatehouse, gates and mounting block,&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Gatehouse, gates and mounting block | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33311 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; infirmary&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=Infirmary | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33314 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; and west wall&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web | title=West wall | work=[[Images of England]]|publisher=[[English Heritage]] | url=http://www.imagesofengland.org.uk/details/default.aspx?id=33313 | accessdate=19 October 2007}}&lt;/ref&gt; are also listed buildings.
|-
| [[Yeovil Railway Centre]] ||[[File:Turntable at Yeovil Junction station.jpg|100px]] ||[[Yeovil]]&lt;br&gt;&lt;small&gt;{{coord|50.9242|-2.6128|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Yeovil Railway Centre}}&lt;/small&gt; || [[South Somerset]] || Railway || Created in 1993 in response to [[British Rail]]'s decision to remove the [[Turntable (rail)|turntable]] from Yeovil Junction. Approximately a {{frac|1|4}} mile of track along the Clifton Maybank spur is used for demonstration trains. The site contains a [[Great Western Railway]] [[Goods shed|transfer shed]] built in the 1860s, which was erected to facilitate the transfer of goods from {{RailGauge|84}} [[broad gauge]] to {{RailGauge|ussg}} [[standard gauge]] freight wagons. This is the last remaining shed of its type and has been converted to a visitor centre. The site also has an [[Southern Railway (Great Britain)|S.R.]] [[turntable (rail)|turntable]] and a {{convert|15000|impgal|adj=on}} [[water tower]].&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Yeovil Railway Centre|url=http://www.yeovilrailway.freeservers.com|publisher=Yeovil Railway Centre|accessdate=30 May 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
|}

==Defunct museums==
The [[Peat Moors Centre]], [[Westhay]], was dedicated to the [[archaeology]], [[history]] and [[geology]] of the [[Somerset Levels]]. It also included reconstructions of some of the archaeological discoveries, including a number of [[Iron Age]] round houses from [[Glastonbury Lake Village]], and the world's oldest engineered highway, the [[Sweet Track]]. The museum closed in 2009 and its status remains uncertain.&lt;ref&gt;{{cite web|title=Peat Moors Centre|url=http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=6886&amp;mode=&amp;order=0&amp;thold=0|publisher=Magalithic Portal|accessdate=6 June 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt;
